title: 109_s2475
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Commission to Study the Potential Creation of a National Museum of the American Latino Community Act of 2006". It establishes a commission. The Commission to Study the Potential Creation of a National Museum of the American Latino Community is established with 23 members appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, Senate leaders, and others. Members must have a commitment to research or study. The Commission to Study the Potential Creation of a National Museum of the American Latino Community is looking for individuals with expertise in museum administration, fundraising, teaching Latino culture, studying Smithsonian representation, or experience in public service. They also seek individuals with experience in planning museums focused on ethnic groups in American history. The Commission to Study the Potential Creation of a National Museum of the American Latino Community is seeking individuals with expertise in museum administration, fundraising, teaching Latino culture, studying Smithsonian representation, or experience in public service. They are also looking for individuals with experience in planning museums focused on ethnic groups in American history. The functions of the Commission are outlined in Section 3. The Commission is tasked with submitting a report to the President and Congress on a plan for establishing and maintaining a National Museum of the American Latino Community in Washington, DC. This includes developing fundraising plans and examining issues such as collection availability, impact on regional museums, and possible locations for the Museum. The Commission will submit recommendations for a legislative plan to create and construct the National Museum of the American Latino Community in consultation with various committees. They will also engage the American Latino community in the development and design of the Museum. The Commission will convene a national conference on the Museum, comprised of individuals committed to the advancement of American Latino life, art, history, and culture, within 9 months of the enactment of the legislative plan for the Museum's creation. SEC. 4. ADMINISTRATIVE PROVISIONS.

The Secretary of the Interior will provide necessary administrative services, facilities, and funds for the Commission. Members not federal employees may receive compensation and travel expenses as determined by the Secretary.

SEC. 5. DEADLINE FOR SUBMISSION OF REPORTS; TERMINATION.

The Commission must submit final reports, plans, and recommendations within 18 months of the Act's enactment. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting the final versions of reports. Authorization of appropriations for the Commission is set at $2,100,000 for fiscal year 2007 and $1,100,000 for fiscal year 2008.
